titleInfo.title: Essays on Collaborative Governance Mechanisms to Address Gender-Based Violence and Inequalities

name.namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
School of Public Administration and Policy

mods:mods.abstract: Gender-based violence (GBV) is deeply rooted in gender inequalities (re) produced by patriarchal formal and informal institutions, including the government. Gender inequalities intersect with other structural inequalities based on race, ethnicity, class, and disability, among others, placing differential burdens on marginalized social groups regarding their experiences with government policies aimed at addressing GBV. Historically, feminist and grass-roots organizations have advocated and worked for the implementation of public policies that recognize, address, and prevent GBV and inequalities. However, governments have faced different challenges to provide policy responses that go beyond punitivist and essentialist (i.e., single-axis views) approaches to GBV, to formalize adequate governance structures to reduce implementation and coordination failures, and to institutionalize a gendered perspective into government structures and policies to comprehensively tackle this multifaceted, multidimensional, and intersectional social problem. This dissertation relies on longitudinal analysis and feminist and collaborative governance literature to explore how collective government structures may contribute to broadening policy approaches in the United States, and how collective government structures, gender-sensitive budgeting, and gender action plans are formalized in Argentina. Thereby, it contributes to the literature on purpose-oriented networks by i) analyzing different types of networks with similar purposes but different positions and tasks within the policy subsystem, ii) exploring membership makeup related to more comprehensive policy adoption for more equitable solutions as network outcomes, iii) exploring the influence of national government metagovernance on subnational purpose-oriented networks formalization and makeup, and iv) employing longitudinal analyses, focusing on subnational governments as units of observation, and expanding the geographical scope of the literature to the Global South. These contributions also advance the literature on gender policies by placing the focus on less explored approaches to gender governance, i.e., both the formalization and the influence of collaborative institutional arrangements that include advocates and community-based organizations on gender policies to address GBV and other policy mechanisms to mainstream a gender perspective within public administration and policy.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Askew School of Public Administration and Policy in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Collaborative governance, Gender mainstreaming, Gender-based violence, Metagoverance, Policy networks, Public governance
Daniel Fay, Professor Directing Dissertation; Petra Doan, University Representative; Frances Berry, Committee Member; James E. Wright, II, Committee Member.
